Title: What Business Are We Actually In?
Overall Purpose: To clarify the true nature of our business—beyond products, services, or current markets—so that decisions and strategies align with our real identity and purpose.
Why This Matters: Misunderstanding what business we are truly in leads to misplaced investments, diluted focus, and missed opportunities. Clarity ensures we adapt without losing our essence.
When To Use This Protocol:
During strategic planning or rebranding
When growth opportunities pull in conflicting directions
After a major market shift or disruption
When internal teams have differing views on the organization’s purpose

Overall Outcomes.Poor: We define ourselves by our current outputs only → The future risks irrelevance when markets change.
Overall Outcomes.Expected: We have some sense of our deeper business, but still operate narrowly → The future adapts slowly to change.
Overall Outcomes.Excellent: We clearly articulate and align to our true business → The future stays relevant and focused.
Overall Outcomes.Transcendent: Our true business is embedded in culture—guiding every choice and evolution → The future thrives through change without losing its core.

Themes.Name: Defining the Deeper Business
Themes.Purpose of This Theme: To uncover the fundamental value we deliver, beyond our current products or services.
Themes.Why This Matters: Knowing the deeper business keeps us anchored through shifts in markets, technology, or customer needs.

Poor.Present pattern: We define ourselves only by what we currently sell.
Poor.Signals: All messaging tied to current outputs.
Poor.Edge condition: You avoid abstract or higher-level framing.
Poor.Example moves: Calling ourselves a 'widget company' instead of defining the value behind widgets.

Expected.Present pattern: Some awareness of deeper business, but not applied widely.
Expected.Signals: Leaders use different language for core business.
Expected.Edge condition: You mention deeper purpose but act from narrow scope.

Excellent.Present pattern: Clear articulation of deeper business is shared and applied.
Excellent.Edge condition: You revisit definition as markets evolve.

Transcendent.Present pattern: Deeper business definition is cultural instinct.
Transcendent.Edge condition: You defend deeper business under pressure.
Transcendent.Example moves: Cultural storytelling rooted in deeper business.
Transcendent.Future effect: Core value endures regardless of form.

Guiding Questions: If our current product disappeared, what business would we still be in?
What value do we truly deliver?
How does this show up beyond our offerings?

Themes.Name: Aligning Strategy to True Business
Themes.Purpose of This Theme: To ensure every strategic move reinforces our real identity and value.
Themes.Why This Matters: Strategy built on the wrong business definition will misallocate resources and dilute impact.

Poor.Present pattern: Strategy follows market fads without core alignment.
Poor.Edge condition: You chase opportunities without checking alignment.
Poor.Example moves: Entering unrelated markets for quick wins.

Expected.Present pattern: Some strategic moves align to true business, others don’t.
Expected.Edge condition: You align strategy only when convenient.

Excellent.Present pattern: Strategy consistently aligns to true business.
Excellent.Future effect: Identity and strategy reinforce each other.

Transcendent.Present pattern: Alignment to true business is instinctive and non-negotiable.
Transcendent.Edge condition: You say no to misaligned opportunities regardless of potential gain.

Guiding Questions: Does this strategy reinforce our true business?
What would full alignment look like?

Themes.Name: Communicating the Real Business Internally
Themes.Purpose of This Theme: To make sure everyone inside the organization understands and can articulate the true business.
Themes.Why This Matters: Internal clarity drives consistent decisions, customer experiences, and innovation.

Poor.Present pattern: Staff have different or incorrect ideas of what business we are in.
Poor.Signals: Different answers when asked about the business.
Poor.Example moves: No internal messaging on core business.

Expected.Edge condition: You share vision only in leadership circles.

Excellent.Present pattern: All staff understand and can articulate the real business.
Excellent.Edge condition: You train new hires in business clarity.

Transcendent.Present pattern: Real business clarity is embedded in culture.
Transcendent.Edge condition: You guard internal clarity as strategic asset.

Guiding Questions: Can everyone here articulate what business we’re really in?
How can we embed clarity across the org?

Themes.Name: Listening to the Market’s View
Themes.Purpose of This Theme: To compare our internal view of the business with how customers, partners, and the market see us.
Themes.Why This Matters: A mismatch between internal and external views can signal drift or opportunity.

Poor.Edge condition: You assume market sees you as you see yourself.

Expected.Edge condition: You react only when problems surface.

Excellent.Present pattern: We regularly compare internal identity with market perception.

Transcendent.Edge condition: You see perception tracking as core discipline.

Guiding Questions: How does the market describe us?
Where do they see us differently than we see ourselves?
What does that gap tell us?

Themes.Name: Future-Proofing Our Business Definition
Themes.Purpose of This Theme: To ensure our definition of the business can adapt to future changes in technology, markets, or needs.
Themes.Why This Matters: A static definition can trap us; a flexible one keeps us relevant while protecting identity.

Poor.Present pattern: Definition of business is fixed and product-bound.
Poor.Signals: Inability to adapt without identity crisis.
Poor.Edge condition: You see change as threat to core.

Expected.Signals: Updating business definition only after necessity.

Excellent.Present pattern: Business definition is flexible yet anchored in core value.
Excellent.Signals: Ease in exploring new forms of value.

Transcendent.Edge condition: You treat adaptability as part of identity.

Guiding Questions: Will this definition still be true in 5–10 years?
What forms could our value take in the future?
How can we evolve without losing our essence?

Completion Prompts: Capture one insight about our true business identity to share with your team.
Identify one strategic move that aligns with our core business identity.
Reflect on how you can communicate our real business purpose in your daily work.
